												I've played for years and it is absolutely the best racing simulation out there. Well optimized, I've never suffered any stutter or lag whatsoever. Graphics may not be absolutely cutting edge by todays standards, but there is certainly not anything lacking in the visual department. ( The actual game looks much better than the promo videos, believe me ) I do find that user made skins available at mod sites generally look superior to the stock car skins. 												Race’07 is simply a must to any real sim racer’s library. It is quite simply the best touring car experience out there. I've put hundreds of hours into this sim, most of which doing competitive league and championship racing at Race2Play.com. The features and details this sim has to offer, especially at the time of its release, were second to none. Comprehensive tire model, very rich setup with (most) cars responding very well to the setup changes, best FWD touring car or similar experience to date, windscreen and visor bug splats/mud with helmets having tear-offs, lots of good add-ons (particularly Retro Expansion!) which gave a variety of cars and more tracks such as the entire Green Hell and a barrage of GT1 - GT3 content with the GTREvo expansion.The GT car physics are sub-par, I'll be honest. GTR2 was much better for these and GTRE fails to exploit the same GT experience. The formula cars are kind of a hit and miss. You really need to dive into the setup to get these feeling correctly, but the FMaster and FRR are really fun when you do. Unfortunately the Formula cars in this game use GT car brakes! Grand Prix length events with the FRR, even with full brake duct and lower pressure, will overheat and destroy the brakes. Because they overheat at 600C like the GT brakes, instead of overheating at the F1 range of 1000C, which they can easily reach with higher ambient temperature and heavy brake-load circuits. Unfortunately having my brakes fail in two Grands Prix cost me a very prestigious drivers championship at R2P so I remain bitter about that flaw.But all-in-all the setup depth and complexity and telemetry coming off the car, the amount of cars and the detail put into the individual physics for each (even model-by-model in classes!) is amazing, the detail of the tracks including the bumps and undulations of the surface make driving a F1 or GT1 car on the edge in league racing incredibly intense, and just.. yeah. It's a sim, not an arcade game. If you take the time to learn how to setup each car, push yourself to be consistent and drive it like a sim - drive it like you would a real car - setup your FFB to really feel the front suspension weight transfers this is a driving sim experience like no other!

												The 'Race' series comes from a little Swedish company called Simbin, not the most evocotive name. But when you take the entire series as a whole, they have created an absolute master piece of PC gaming.Race 07, the core game of the series, is primarily focused on the WTCC (World Touring Car Championsip) for 2007, along with serveral 'support' series you can race also. Having learnt leassons from previous racing sims, Simbin have just kept adding to the game, & despite the final collection numbering near double figures, the game is still stable, reliable & entertaining as day one.The one thing that should grab the attention of serious racing-sim fans is the fact that behind the less glamourous series' is in fact nothing less than a licensed version of the rFactor engine, a sim that has gone beyond being a game, it is tool that is even used by top racing teams to train professional drivers!Once you have the full works of the Race series, you can race everything from Caterhams, MINI Coopers, WTCC cars of various series, Formula BMW, GT cars, muscle cars... The number of different cars on offer is quite astounding.However, the real bonus to the Race series is that Simbin have left the game entirely open to being heavily modded, & in fact, have made allowances for making the game easy to mod, from car skins, to tracks, graphics tweaks to entirely new cars that have never existed in the game. Despite having added a huge number of mods of various types to my install, the game remains stable & utterly reliable, something that could quite easily be the make or break of a modding favourite.On the downside, you pretty much need the whole hog to ensure mods will work, meaning you do have to commit to it. Also, given the quality of the 'sim' part, if you don't have, or never intend to, get a steering wheel, don't bother with it, you'll just be wasting the game & not getting the full experience.It adds up to a game where you can race almost anything you want to, on pretty much any track you like. There are even online racing clubs who use the game.I've reached a point where I actually wouldn't even consider buying new racing sims as Race has everything I need, with all the quality & realism of a truly great game that could only be this great on a PC.

												Don't be deceived by the age or the price of this game. It's very good.The amount and variety of content puts many later titles to shame, and so does the AI.For the first time in a long time, I can race the AI without simply strolling through the pack or watching a single file of cars disappear over the horizon leaving me to hot lap alone. In addition, I have yet to be rear ended or shoved off the track by the AI, no matter where I am on track or how slow I am going. If you have track position, the AI will respect that as best it can, however if you try things like cheap late dives up the inside, they will hold their line and you will get clumped. This enables you to battle with the AI for fun under proper 'Queensbury Rules', which is how it should be.The only other game I can think of at the moment that has AI close to this is Stock Car Extreme.In addition, the AI cars also have their own little battles between themselves from time to time which helps greatly with the immersion and I have yet to see any AI cars get bunched up and stuck anywhere. (Quick Tip: Don't max out the number of AI cars when you race. Keep the AI numbers on the low side and this will further help to avoid congestion.)Graphics are fine, and with a little graphics card tweaking (anti-aliasing in particular) it can be made to look very nice - not photo realistic, no - but still nice looking. Smooth and and clean.Force feedback is also good if you take the time to tweak the settings to your liking. One advantage of being an older game is that there's plenty of information on the internet to help set up most wheels properly.Kudos also for the clean and clear user interface. Everything is laid out logically, and setting up races and competitions (you can also create your own custom competitions by the way) follows a nice logical flow through track and car selection to get you to race day.So, if you're at all frustrated whilst waiting for a fix or patch on your latest photo-realistic uber-racing sim, do yourself a favour - spend £2.50 on this and have some serious fun in the mean time.Highly recommended.P.S. I've spent quite a bit more time playing this game than the numbers above would indicate, before writing this review. :)

												For less than the price of 2 pieces of bread sandwiching some sort of delicious filling, you will not find a better value racing game. Sure, it's 7 years old now, but that doesn't matter. That means even if your PC isn't crammed with the latest technology, you'll still be able to run it. The handelling may not be entirely 100% sim-like, but it's close enough and means you can play with a controller just as well as a wheel and pedals. Lotso race options available, from 3 lap sprints to 120 minute endurances, fully tyre wear, fuel depletion, damage modelling, engine and gearbox failures, sliding scale AI so no matter how good or bad you are you'll be challenged. There's still a healthy online community playing and modding this game at the likes of RaceDepartment or ReallyRubbishRacing. And all of this before you even take into account the increibly cheap expansion packs that add even more circuits and cars to play with.Cannot recommend enough as an entry into sim racing, and a game you'll no doub continue playing into the future. 												Race 07 is an excellent entry-level simulator for the PC. It does require you to use some sort of controller other than a keyboard and mouse, but can easily be controlled with the stuff you probably already own, like a Dualshock III or Xbox controller.The expansion packs are worth it, especially GTR Evolution for us who need a bit more speed than what touring cars can offer.The community creates a lot of free tracks and cars that are excellent for making the game last a lot longer.On the downside of things, the force feedback in this game compared to earlier Simbin titles like GTR2 is horrible. You don't get that distinct feel of lack of grip when understeering, a vital thing in a game with mostly FWD cars.The graphics are very dated by now, and no mod seems to freshen them up properly. Creating your own skins do help a bit though, something I do a lot. All in all, for its age, Race07 is around an 8/10 because of the lack of proper FFB and lack of "fast" racing cars. 												First of all I'd like to mention the good stuff. The game is a great package for the money. I haven't heard of another realistic racing sim you could pick up for that little cash. It takes itself very seriously and is very driver focused. It looks like the real deal most of the time (the rules, the damage, the race weekend etc). You can also make comprehensive adjustments to your car and there's a good selection of different tracks. However the game looks like something that would come with a box of cereal, meaning extremely cheap (check the price once again). The car selection is woefully small (half of them comprising of caterhams and radicals with different power outputs). There are a lot of customizing options as mentioned, but they didn't bother to explain what kind of effect these changes would have on the cars performance or at least mentioning the basics of car setup. The AI are like oiled up bricks and don't make a satisfying opponent. If by any chance you find yourself off the tarmac, then you're essentially on rails, because you can't steer or break or accelerate. The cars themselves (mainly with stability control off) are far too nervous and unbalanced meaning they will frequently spin (especially high hp cars). This results in extreme effort put into driving clean, fast laps, but the rewards are not in any way satisying. Not once was I smiling whilst playing this game. I could kind of tolerate much of it, but the idiotic driving characteristics was the last straw - the gear you're in, affects the understeer going into a corner and also the braking distance. Also cars with maximum amount of downforce, happily skidded about. And once you start putting on a few dlc-s (to get more cars and tracks), the price climbs quickly (20eur+) and it just can't compete with the alternative titles.Overall a good racing sim if you're in need of a racing game for less than 5 eur or if you're into a challenging realistic (as good as they came in 2007) racing experience then give it a go. But there  are so many far better alternatives to this game that I don't see the need for a regular car guy to own this.

You fire it up, pick a car, and your plumped onto a track. The engines shut off. Ok that’s neat, but how do I start it?  Duck into the settings and assign a key…  Ok great the motors started here we… ugh I stalled it, better assign a clutch button on my controller… Ok here we go, turn right to exit the pits… oh my god is that what it feels like steering in this game!? And also the guy in second place closed our gap by a lap. That was a little terrifying.Anyway, if you got this game for free, give it a shot because you might get some fun out of it. Despite what it says it actually does have 360 controller support. Other than that, don't spend money on this game. You'll regret it.In the meantime, I may come back to this and see if I can make better sense out of it. Maybe that's the key to enjoying this game.

												You know what this is? It's a game. I mention that only because the creators seem to think they have actually built a magical device that is a REAL racing experience. But it's not. It is a program on a computer, and frankly not a very good one either. The problem with so many of these "racing sims" is that the people playing them and the people making them will not acknowledge the fact that these are games, built for entertainment value. The view of the world from inside a car is a whole hell of a lot different from one sitting in front of a computer screen. The same rules don't apply. For instance, no matter how good a setup you may have you will never actually be able to feel the car tires start to lose grip. This is a very, very important part of driving that you cannot replicate. But let's be honest here; 99.9% of the people who play games don't have a wheel and pedals and a racing chair - it's just too expensive. Most people will be playing these games with controlers, and will only have a few hours at a time to dedicate to playing. It takes years to learn how to be a real race car driver, and frankly if the people playing these games could be racing car drivers they wouldn't be playing a frankly appaling port of their job. This is a game, but because the makers of this game refuse to admit that it is a game, it's not very good. Unless you are a harcore racing game fanatic, you will hate this game. if you are a hardcore racing game fanatic you will be playing something much better, like Project Cars. This is a game with no real dempographic, and it really shows. Lot's of technical detail, very little enjoyment. I paid $2 for a bundle of seven racing games and I guess this is a classic example of caveat emptor. I got what I paid for.

												First things first: This game is perfectly playable - and vastly enjoyable - with a gamepad. There. I said it.I'm not saying that it is the BEST way to get the MOST out of the game but the reviews I'm seeing posted that state the game is only playable with a steering wheel are misleading at best. The only thing that will ruin this great game is a lack of patience. And it does require patience! If I flick the thumbstick too much the car spins; if I squeeze the trigger too much while trying to turn the car spins; one wheel off the track and on the grass? Guess what? The car spins!However, after a couple of hours focussing on one car (Mini Cooper) on one track (Brands Hatch) I eventually became accustomed to the physics of the game and began to put in some pretty decent lap times. Then, emboldened, I even started removing some of the driving assists. After more hours I became very comfortable and was putting in consistently quick laps. Now I've just got to learn how to handle the rest of the cars. And how to race round the rest of the tracks. And I can't wait.If you have patience and either a gaming wheel or a gamepad, buy this game - it's all of £2.49! It is so much more rewarding than any other racing game I have played. Also, there is a modding community that is still very active and has done a great job professionally recreating pretty much every circuit ever raced on. So if you fancy taking a Touring Car or a Formula 3000 car for a spin (literally in my case!) around Snetterton, Aintree, Sepang or even the Top Gear test track then this is the game for you.

												First things first: This game is perfectly playable - and vastly enjoyable - with a gamepad. There. I said it.I'm not saying that it is the BEST way to get the MOST out of the game but the reviews I'm seeing posted that state the game is only playable with a steering wheel are misleading at best. The only thing that will ruin this great game is a lack of patience. And it does require patience! If I flick the thumbstick too much the car spins; if I squeeze the trigger too much while trying to turn the car spins; one wheel off the track and on the grass? Guess what? The car spins!However, after a couple of hours focussing on one car (Mini Cooper) on one track (Brands Hatch) I eventually became accustomed to the physics of the game and began to put in some pretty decent lap times. Then, emboldened, I even started removing some of the driving assists. After more hours I became very comfortable and was putting in consistently quick laps. Now I've just got to learn how to handle the rest of the cars. And how to race round the rest of the tracks. And I can't wait.If you have patience and either a gaming wheel or a gamepad, buy this game - it's all of £2.49! It is so much more rewarding than any other racing game I have played. Also, there is a modding community that is still very active and has done a great job professionally recreating pretty much every circuit ever raced on. So if you fancy taking a Touring Car or a Formula 3000 car for a spin (literally in my case!) around Snetterton, Aintree, Sepang or even the Top Gear test track then this is the game for you.

												I read the reviews and purchased RACE 07 low on funds and looking for something different from my other games. Glad I did! This game is now one of my favorites. Not having a wheel and only using a mouse and keyboard, I was a bit concerned if it would be all that playable. Rest assure it's not only playable, but downright fun! If you use the keyboard and mouse, by editing the settings and keeping most of the auto settings on, you can for the most part play with just a mouse alone, You probably couldn't keep up with the big boys and gals online though, also after a couple hours of straight racing my hand tends to cramp up due to tightnig my grip to steer.The replay viewer and camera controls are another plus. You can go back and watch where you messed up or find out what exactly caused that multi-car pile up. Yes, the graphics are a bit dated, but when your doing 110+ mph and coming up on a hairpin curve, with bumper to bumper cars, you really should be paying more attention to your driving and not enjoying the scenery, This ain't a Sunday drive game! Still, the graphics are better than expected and my laptop running Windows 10 an intel core i3-4030U CPU, 6GB RAM, with built in Intel 4400 HD Graphics has no problem running this game smoothly with everything set to max. Your mileage may vary depending on make and model, so I can't say how good your performance will be.Haven't tried the multiplayer due to a poor internet connection, so being able to play offline is just about a must and RACE 07 allows you to do just that.More free mods, car skins and tracks can be found online by doing a search, but read the descriptions and install instructions carefully, with so much DLC addon content available for 07, some downloads require you to have more than just the base game.I see a wheel and more of the DLC content being added in the near future, best purchse value for the fun in a long time!Thanks
